;今天，许多力量正在以前所未有的方式汇聚在一起，重塑工作的本质。为了理解和适应这些力量，领导者需要开始认真思考三个重要的关注领域：;工人;的未来（他们质疑工作在生活中所扮演的角色，并对组织提出更多要求他们为之工作）； ;工作;的未来（由于混合和灵活的工作安排、数字化和自动化，工作正在迅速发展）；以及工作本身的未来（总是涉及对宏观力量和社会转变的反应）。作者将这三个领域称为工作的;谁;、;什么;和;为什么;。每个人都有自己特定的挑战。领导者需要面对并解决这些挑战，本文作者就如何最好地做到这一点提供了建议。

;
;
;
;

;

;过去几年的特点是一代-定义危机——政治、经济、社会和环境。我们曾经认为工作世界理所当然的许多事情已经受到质疑，许多以前难以想象的事情现在已经成为日常生活的事实。但流失还远未结束。正如一家全球咨询公司最近招聘的一名员工告诉我们的那样，“我们的工作生活正处于巨大剧变的开始，而不是结束。”

;

;这些剧变引发了有关未来的各种问题。工作的。我们要去哪里？未来会怎样？领导者该如何准备？在推动组织向前发展时，他们应该关注什么？数字化和人工智能快速增长的能力？转向混合工作有何影响？员工福祉？千禧一代和婴儿潮一代的优先事项发生变化？社会和环境责任问题？不稳定的地缘政治环境和不明朗的经济未来？

;

;面对这些多重竞争但又相互依赖的问题，领导人感到不知所措，这是可以理解的。上述咨询公司的首席执行官告诉我们：“我已尽我所能，让这家公司在疫情期间团结一致。” “当我思考未来挑战的规模时，我觉得我已经没有什么可以奉献的了。”

;

;我们是领导力、可持续性和组织变革的学者。近年来，我们将注意力集中在领导者和组织如何才能最好地应对这些挑战。我们在学术研究和专业咨询中了解到，如果领导者希望了解并适应正在重塑工作的力量，他们将需要开始更具体地思考三个重要领域：关注点：1) ;工人;的未来，2）;工作;的未来，以及 3）;工作;本身的未来。

;

;换句话说，工作的;谁;、;什么;和;为什么;。

;

;工作的三个领域关注

;

;工作的;谁;、;什么;和;为什么;紧密相连。思考它们之间的关系并不能帮助我们准确预测未来，但可以帮助我们做好准备。因此，让我们依次考虑每一个。

;

;工人（;谁;）的未来。

;

;流行病引起的内省和封锁带来的打破框架的经历已经导致很多人质疑工作在生活中的作用。他们提出深刻的问题，了解他们的组织对他们的要求，并质疑他们的组织是否值得他们的承诺。与此同时，他们常常要求有权在工作中更多地展现“完整的自我”，这迫使领导者比过去更加关注员工的性别、种族等问题。 、宗教和性。

; ; ;
; ;
;
; 洞察中心集合
;

;工作的未来

;
; 您的公司会适应还是被抛在后面？
;
; ;
; ; ;

;但是，过于专注于满足不同个人需求的领导者可能会忽视大局。员工对工作的疑问和担忧源于两种强大力量之间的碰撞：一方面是当今的宏观社会经济现实，另一方面是长期以来对属于组织和做好“好”工作的理解。其他。对未来工作的任何反思都必须评估“谁”的这种不断变化的状态，以及它与“什么”和“为什么”的关系。; p>;

;工作的未来（;什么;）。

;

;混合、远程和灵活的工作将继续存在。尽管试图迫使员工返回办公室，但远程工作的水平仍然比大流行之前高出四到五倍。这些新做法从根本上改变了人们的工作方式、工作地点和工作时间，但其后果尚未完全了解。

;

;领导人感到自己面临着宣布“标准化”政策的压力，以此作为一种方式在令人不安的模糊性中提供一些令人放心的确定性。但在当前不稳定的宏观背景下，我们应该如何工作的确定感只能是虚幻和短暂的。

;

;与此同时，数字化正在迅速重塑人与机器交互的方式，影响着我们所做的任务、我们所扮演的角色，以及指导和支持我们的组织安排。到 2030 年代中期，多达 30% 的工作可能面临自动化风险，而当今人工智能的快速发展使未来进入现实的速度比大多数人的预测要快得多。领导者如何塑造因快速发展的技术系统而不断变化的工作环境和员工任务？

;

;工作的未来（;原因;）。

;

;随着我们适应新能源基础设施、人口老龄化以及更炎热、更动荡的地球，长期宏观力量和短期冲击正在对企业提出一系列新的要求。供应链中断变得越来越频繁。政治事件也引发了公众情绪的快速转变——例如，关于种族不平等或与俄罗斯和中国的商业关系。除了这些宏观变化之外，人们的愿望和行动也在不断变化，反映出价值观、愿望和生活选择方面日益加深的差异。

;

;一些领导人正在以新的目标声明做出回应，定义他们将如何与股东一起服务社会需求”日益多样化的期望。但这些着眼长远的尝试充满了短期的模糊性，因为重新定义企业在社会中的角色的举措引发了强烈反对。这是可以预料的，因为我们正在经历文化转变，并开始对“好的企业是什么样子”以及好的工作包含什么有新的理解。

;

;我们拥有比我们想象的更多的代理权

;

;我们拥有比我们想象的更多的代理权

;

; h2>;

;正在重塑工作的人、内容和原因的剧变感觉超出了我们的控制范围，并且在某种程度上这种情况将持续下去。即使前进的方向是明确的，没有人可以确定地预测下一次行动或人类危机何时何地会发生，也不能确定它是否会由技术、战争、气候或社会动荡引发。重新获得能动性首先要认识到我们在这个复杂系统中的角色，并注意工人、工作和工作本身是如何交织在一起的。最终，工作的未来并不“就在那里”。它在我们和我们的组织内部，我们可以通过下面概述的步骤与我们的同事一起塑造它。

;

;集体领导克服不确定性。

;

;对于复杂的环境和地缘政治挑战，通常是承认局部行动的效果有限，解决办法在于集体行动。正如单独行动的国家在应对复杂的系统级挑战方面软弱且无效一样，组织中的领导者也是如此。为了应对未来工作的挑战，领导者需要明白，他们的责任不是个人责任，而是集体责任，将整个组织内的同事组成一个复杂的联盟。 ;集体领导;是未来工作的核心组成部分。

;

;记住疲惫不堪的咨询-我们在本文开头提到的公司首席执行官，谁觉得自己“没有什么可给予的”？他对塑造组织未来工作的责任感感到负担过重。但他不应该独自承担这个责任。负担是集体的。他的工作是召集整个组织各级潜在的领导者来解决这个问题，扩大集体见解，并遏制情绪上的不确定性。

;

;扩大集体见解。

;

;当前工作世界中挑战的复杂性跨越层级、代际、职能和地域。这些问题只能通过将具有竞争利益的多组利益相关者聚集在一起来解决，这些利益相关者共同可以产生广泛的见解并帮助组织及其领导者成功应对不确定性。根据定义，组织高层在短期内损失最大，因此可能会拒绝提出有关未来的最具挑战性的问题。与此同时，从长远来看，最年轻的员工获益最多，因为现状对他们来说没有什么价值。因此，与我们合作的许多组织都在探索如何将新的和陌生的声音融入到他们的领导力讨论中。

;

;控制情绪上的不确定性。

;

;虽然领导者需要与各个方面进行接触他们的组织为了激发和维持领导力举措，他们还需要建立一些情感护栏。领导者在任何时候的一个关键作用就是找出如何最好地平衡个人的自主需求和组织的控制需求。虽然年轻的同事尤其可能渴望自主权和机会来追求自己的工作激情，但他们仍然需要相信组织的集体身份及其在组织中的地位。领导者应提醒员工组织过去的最佳方面，重申他们的文化身份，并为建设集体未来奠定坚实的基础。

;

;< strong>;* * *;

;

;最终，我们都希望属于比我们自己更伟大、值得致力于的事物。但我们所属的组织已经发生了变化，;我们也发生了变化;。面对不断累积的巨大挑战，人们很容易放弃这些挑战，尝试像“正常”一样继续生活。但是，当旧的正常感不再相关时，就像当今工作世界的情况一样，我们必须学会如何清楚地思考正在发生的事情。我们必须认识到，只有为自己创造一种新的常态感，适应而不是抵制模糊性和持续的不确定性，我们才能最终理解这个困难而令人兴奋的变革时期。这根本不是我们能够孤立地完成的事情。但在我们的组织内，专注于集体领导，我们可以开始共同努力。

;向员工交付企业技术也是如此。一刀切的策略可能会松散地满足某些员工的需求，但不是全部。

;

;一些成功的组织已经采用了一种有希望的替代方案：角色映射，即识别个人（或角色）在您的组织内，并定制您为每个角色组提供的技术体验。这是“用户就是用户”思维方式的转变，将每个员工映射到他们所服务的业务职能。

;

;对于任何优先考虑业务以了解和完善员工体验的组织来说，角色映射是必须的（ EXs）您提供。通过创建角色组，您可以衡量和优化企业技术的业务影响。

;

;;角色映射如何优化 IT 服务交付？ ;

;

;角色映射使您的 IT 团队能够识别每个员工的独特需求，而不是专注于一般最终用户的总体情况。除了改进 EX 之外，角色映射策略还可以与组织优先事项保持一致，从而更轻松地实现关键业务成果。

;
;
;
; ;
;
;
;

;此处是角色映射的众多应用程序中的两个。

;

;;;帮助台票证路由;;

;

;组织常常难以有效地分配有限的 IT 支持资源并确定服务票据的优先级，尤其是在涉及多个专业服务台时。想象一下，向服务台代理解释您的问题，然后将其转移给其他代理，然后要求您重述问题的详细信息。这种低效率可能会导致员工寻求帮助时出现令人沮丧的延误。我们致力于提供更好的客户服务并缩短响应时间。

;

;当员工联系服务台时，动态查找系统会识别他们的角色组并立即将他们引导至正确的专家。现场销售人员可能会被直接派往专门从事其特定销售软件的团队，而医疗保健工作者可能会被引导到熟悉医院电子病历系统的专家那里。这种方法不仅改善了支持体验，还提高了员工的工作效率。

;

;;;设备更新;;

;

;采用角色驱动的方法设备生命周期管理可确保您的员工拥有实现最佳性能所需的工具。使用重型应用程序的工程师可能需要频繁的设备更新，而偶尔的设备升级对于销售人员来说可能就足够了，从而节省成本并有利于环境。

;

;此外，一线员工（例如使用公司平板电脑的航空公司机组人员）也可以受益于量身定制的支持解决方案。在简报中心或为机场工作人员提供“设备帮助”按钮提供支持，可确保高效的现场故障排除，而不会给乘客带来不便。

;

;;您如何选择角色？;

;
;
;
; ;
;
;
;

;您的组织应创建的角色数量取决于什么对 IT 来说既可管理又有用。如果您不熟悉角色映射，请从最多十个角色开始，以平衡利益和管理简便性。可以根据需要进行扩展。

;

;请记住，角色不应仅根据工作角色进行调整，因为角色在技术需求方面可能存在很大差异。相反，应根据具有相似需求的员工群体创建角色，例如由财务、法律和营销人员组成的团队或基于地理位置的其他团队。

;

;在开发角色时，请考虑以下关键因素：

;

; p>;

    ;
  • ;;资历和角色：;高级管理人员和关键任务员工（例如创伤中心医生）可能需要优先 IT 支持。组织通常会为此类角色创建 VIP 角色。
    • ;
  • ;;客户体验：;面向客户的角色（例如零售员工）可能需要更快的支持，以尽量减少停机时间及其对客户的影响经验。
    • ;
  • ;;地点：;制造工厂的员工可能需要立即获得一级服务台的关注，以避免代价高昂的停机。基于位置的角色还有助于为远程和办公室员工定制服务。
    • ;
;

;一些员工可能适合多个角色，例如既面向客户又资历较高的医生。在这种情况下，建立一个流程来帮助 IT 部门决定在不同场景中哪个角色优先。无论在什么情况下，了解每个用户角色生活中的一天都是必须的。

;

;;设置角色映射涉及哪些内容？ ;

;

;; ;角色映射涉及定性研究，通常通过与关键利益相关者举行研讨会来了解员工的技术需求和日常体验。然而，仅仅列出人物角色是不够的；还需要列出人物角色。需要进行大量工程才能将这些数据映射到您的身份数据库中，以提供定制的 IT 服务。采用的一个常见障碍是角色的规划、实施和维护责任不明确。为了避免挫折，尽早组建专门的团队并明确利益相关者的责任至关重要。

;

;;通过角色映射最大限度地提高您的业务价值;

;

;确定 IT 资源的优先级基于角色，更好地通知设备更新、服务票据路由、EX 计划和其他业务流程。角色映射可以帮助您的员工提供更好的客户成果，从而提高客户忠诚度和续订率。与一刀切的 T 恤不同，角色映射可以更好地适合每个人。

; ;摘要。   ; ;

;最近的研究揭示了一个令人不安的趋势：业务集团中的顶尖公司往往在没有采取实质性行动的情况下促进可持续发展。作者分析了 35 个国家 515 家公司的数据，发现顶尖公司，尤其是那些与附属公司共享品牌的公司，与低级别同行相比，较少参与可持续发展举措。这种潜在的“绿色清洗”可能会产生。由于独特的 BG 结构，顶尖公司充当沟通者，附属公司充当实施者，因此可能会被容忍。尽管市场有容忍度，但这种差异可能会损害长期声誉。为了真正的可持续发展，公司必须确保准确的沟通，用共同的价值观激励附属公司，在整个集团范围内传播最佳实践，并适应不断变化的利益相关者的期望。可持续发展不仅仅是一种象征性的姿态，而是一种需要一致、实质性行动的承诺。

; ;
;
;
;
;

;

;可持续发展已迅速成为公司治理不可或缺的一部分。但随着企业致力于绿色实践，一个令人担忧的趋势也浮现出来：一些企业将自己描绘成绿色企业，却未能以具体行动来支持自己的主张。例子不胜枚举：英国广告标准局 (ASA) 最近禁止了一些知名公司的广告，其中包括;汇丰银行< /a>; 在应对气候变化的努力上“误导”。 ASA 还;禁止瑞安航空的广告;，因为该公司未经证实地声称自己是欧洲排放最低的航空公司。

;

;此外对于监管机构来说，那些塑造未经证实的绿色形象的公司也会受到投资者和消费者的谴责，他们可能会通过 ;处罚;，;撤资;，;抵制;，甚至;抗议< /a>;.然而，我们最近的研究表明，一些公司可能会采取类似的行为，同时在一定程度上逃避审查和制裁。所谓的商业集团（BG）——似乎在很大程度上避免了对绿色清洗的审查。企业集团在全球发展中经济体和发达经济体中都是普遍存在但尚未得到充分研究的实体，在印度、韩国、土耳其和智利等不同国家的经济活动中占据很大一部分（即使不是大部分）。每个BG本质上是一个由附属公司组成的网络，这些公司通常跨越多个行业，共享资源，并通过股权和社会关系相互联系。 BG 中的公司通常由核心或顶级公司协调，而这些公司通常是最高企业所有者。; ;我们的研究揭示了这些安排中的一个奇怪的动态：我们发现顶级公司能够报告“免费”地评价其下层附属公司的可持续发展努力，即无需用自己的行动来证实它们。他们可以做到这一点，而不会被贴上洗绿标签。

;

;为了阐明这一现象，我们分析了来自 35 个不同国家的 515 家 BG 成员的上市公司的数据。具体来说，我们从 Refinitiv（以前称为 ASSET4）获取了环境、社会和治理 (ESG) 数据，该数据根据公司报告的信息衡量每家公司相对于行业同行的 ESG 绩效。我们用它来区分公司的实质性可持续发展行动（即与社会责任政策和计划相关的行动）和象征性行动（即报告、声明或披露）。这两组行动之间的差距是我们衡量公司“空谈”与“行动”脱钩程度的指标。

;

;我们发现，尽管在可持续发展方面的沟通水平相似，顶尖公司参与的实质性可持续行动较少给他们的下层附属公司。换句话说，相对于其他集团成员，这些公司系统地“做广告”比他们实际“做”的多。为这种动态增添了另一层，我们观察到，与没有共享名称的顶级公司相比，与其附属公司共享品牌名称的顶级公司参与的实质性可持续发展行动甚至更少。不幸的是，与较低级别的附属公司相比，股票市场似乎对顶级公司的这种特殊类型的绿色清洗有一定的容忍度。

;

;如何解释这种差异？在其他地方可能被视为公然洗绿的行为可能会被解释为独特的 BG 生态系统中的合法分工。顶尖公司可以利用其影响力和象征性力量充当“沟通者”，扩大集团的整体可持续发展举措；相比之下，较低层的附属公司则扮演“实施者”的角色，实质性地实施这些举措。

;

;这可能为本质上试图搭全球便车的顶尖公司提供短期优势。可持续发展运动。然而，重要的是要认识到，市场对顶尖企业明显的“绿色清洗”行为的容忍并不能免除它们的责任。最终，漂绿可能会严重损害长期声誉并侵蚀利益相关者的信任。领导者应抓住这一认识作为加强其可持续发展实践和报告的机会。事实上，我们的研究对管理者具有重要意义，不仅是在企业集团内部，更广泛的是，在附属于其他公司的公司内（例如，通过联盟和合资企业）。

;

;;诚实对待可持续发展;

;

;如果言辞与现实之间的差距暴露出来，夸大可持续发展努力可能会严重适得其反。就像一个附属机构的良好声誉会对整个集团产生良好的影响一样，洗绿丑闻也会给受影响的附属机构带来不好的影响。因此，领导者应确保有关可持续发展的公共沟通准确反映集团的实际做法。他们应该报告并纠正可持续发展行动和沟通之间的潜在差异。此外，通过外部保证服务建立全面的监控可以提高透明度和问责制，减少被认为是绿色清洗的机会。

;

;;通过共同的身份激励附属公司的可持续发展。;

;

;顶级公司的领导者不应仅仅依靠他们在集团内的协调能力来消除“洗绿”的印象。它们还受益于成为群体认同的来源——包括核心价值观和原则——可以而且应该用来动员群体成员实现长期可持续发展。事实上，许多 BG 通过诉诸他们的历史来做到这一点。例如，日本住友集团 (Sumitomo group) 以其 400 年来关于共同繁荣和尊重公共利益的创始原则（“住友精神”）为基础，推动其可持续发展努力。

;

;;分享可持续发展最佳实践和人才。;

;

;顶级公司的经理不仅应该报告其他附属公司所开展的可持续发展工作，还应该将其分散到集团附属公司。管理人员可以利用BG内完善的内部人力资源网络来招聘擅长企业可持续发展实践的人员，或建立能够在整个集团中识别和传播可持续发展行动的团队。其中一个例子是;塔塔可持续发展集团 (TSG);，它是顶级公司 Tata Sons 的一个团队，其使命是“指导、支持塔塔集团所有公司并提供思想领导力，将可持续发展纳入其业务战略。”换句话说，将顶级公司的沟通作用扩展到内部利益相关者可以帮助制定整个集团的实质性可持续发展战略。

;

;;注意不断变化的利益相关者期望。;

;

;商业世界瞬息万变，利益相关者对可持续发展的期望也不例外。忽视这一演变可能会导致与重要利益相关者（包括客户、员工和投资者）的关系紧张。领导者应努力与他们的期望保持一致，并确保他们对可持续发展的承诺是透明和真实的。

;

;最终，追求可持续发展不是营销噱头，而是需要实质性的承诺，长期行动。强大的群体认同可能会为BG内的顶尖公司提供一些保护，但在其之下，受众、利益相关者乃至整个世界都要求采取实质性的行动，而不仅仅是象征性的行动。特别是在业务部门和类似组织设置的背景下，任何声誉损害都可能波及整个公司集团，严重损害整个组织生态系统。因此，从长远来看，只有真诚致力于可持续实践，公司才能持续受益。

;工作格局正在发生变化，但人们对建立具有道德价值的职业的渴望仍然存在。也就是说，工作必须符合对正确和善良的共同理解。保持不变。虽然这样做很困难，但也是值得的：我们的职业生涯占用了我们大量的时间和精力，而且必须感觉到我们正在创造符合我们道德价值观的职业生涯。作者的观点是：研究表明，人们可以在建立职业生涯的同时坚持自己的道德价值观，方法是适应道德清算的时刻，质疑共同的纯洁规则，并愿意改变他们寻求认可的人。

; ;
;
;
;
;
; ;Leer en español ;

;

;What makes for a satisfying career? As professors, we've taught many young adults preparing to embark on their careers, and we've also studied professionals at all experience levels in a variety of fields, including ;journalists;, ;educators;, architects, ;consultants;, and health care workers. Time and again, in our interactions with students and interviews with professionals, we've observed that people's desire to pursue careers aligned with their moral values is often central to their decisions about which jobs to pursue and which ones to forgo.

;

;Having a “moral career” means doing work that allows one to enact their moral values — in other words, work that aligns with ;shared understandings of what's right and good;. Actually charting a moral career, however, can be challenging. Internal organizational changes as well as uncontrollable socioeconomic shocks can interfere with people's abilities to build moral careers. For instance, in times of economic uncertainty, people must navigate immediate problems like increased cost of living and threats of layoffs, which may in turn require them to make painful trade-offs about the kind of work they do. This was the case for journalists we studied, for whom the precarity of the industry threatened their search for jobs that would allow them to live out their moral value to “tell the truth to society.”

;

;Through our teaching and research, we've gleaned some key lessons about how people can pursue careers that allow them to live out their moral values. These center on tuning into moral reckonings, questioning rules about what kind of work is morally “pure,” and seeking communities that share your moral values. Here's how to put those strategies to work if you're embarking on your own moral career journey.

;

;1. Tune into revelations about the morality of your work.

;

;Professionals often experience ;moral reckonings;: transformational moments that wake us up to misalignments between what we're doing and who we want to be. These reckonings can emerge in the wake of pivotal personal or ;social events;. For example, one person recalled that living through Hurricane Katrina while studying to be an architect had been a “wake-up call” that shaped his career trajectory:

;
;

;I was studying architecture, doing all this theoretical work in a beautiful Richardson Romanesque building that was 120 years old on a [university] campus uptown. At the same time, the city had no infrastructure, and there were piles of trash and bodies still surfacing in homes. I really started to feel a visceral disconnect between what we were studying as perfectly envisioned environments for people and then the realities of what had happened and what was happening with the city of New Orleans.

;
;

;People can also become attuned to moral contradictions as they perform their duties within their organizations. For instance, one nurse we spoke with pointed out that some of the hospital practices that keep the lights on, such as VIP treatment of hospital donors, also promote disparities in equitable health care treatment. Such realizations can accumulate and prompt people come to see the work they do as incompatible with their desire to build a moral career.

;

;Whether triggered by an acute event or a slowly building realization, these moments of revelation can be ambiguous and therefore a source of ;discomfort; and distraction. Our first instinct in the face of discomfort is often to look away, in part because addressing the reckoning might require challenging the status quo. Yet building a moral career requires that you notice, turn toward, and address the discomfort in order to figure out how to shift your career in a moral direction. And indeed, many of the professionals we studied were able to face this discomfort.

;

;2. Question “purity” rules.

;

;Addressing the discomfort that arises from moral reckonings often requires identifying and questioning “purity rules”: shared views about what kind of work — and what kind of job — is morally right. Every professional community shares such a set of rules. Among journalists, for example, jobs in traditional news organizations are often regarded as “pure” because the organizations align themselves with the moral value of telling the unbiased truth about current events. Indeed, The Washington Post's slogan, “Democracy dies in darkness,” attaches clear moral meaning to the work its employees do.

;

;The central assumption behind purity rules is that we should be willing to sacrifice aspects of our personal lives and deprioritize our needs in order to take morally “pure” jobs. For journalists, the personal sacrifice is often salary. One veteran reporter we interviewed explained the trade-off between a moral career and financial stability: “You're telling the truth. You're not spinning. You're trying to be fair in your work. You didn't choose your career to make money. That's why I took a pay cut to move to [a news organization].” But not all personal sacrifices are monetary. For instance, the charter school educators we studied forfeited personal time to dedicate themselves to their students' success. And in one study, international aid workers ;reported sacrificing stable personal relationships; in service of their work.

;

;Over time, it's difficult to keep making these sacrifices. Our work suggests that, in the long term, many people question their fields' generally accepted purity rules and moral status quo and find other creative ways to fulfill their moral values. For example, several journalists we studied decided they were exploited by traditional news media outlets and found nontraditional jobs where they felt they could do work that aligned with their moral values and required fewer personal costs. Some joined universities and research organizations, while others started their own news outlets. In departing from the moral status quo, however, people often find that they have to change the community they look to for moral guidance and validation.

;

;3. Seek communities that share your moral values.

;

;As the examples above show, our moral values and their accompanying trade-offs can be out of alignment with our own career goals. But people are often slow to make a change because they fear that their colleagues and employers will disapprove of their desire to step away from the status quo career. Our research suggests that often, to truly build careers aligned with our moral values, we need to be willing to reconsider whom we seek guidance and validation from. In particular, we need to seek out people who support both our careers and our moral values.

;

;We found that professionals who stay in their jobs but challenge the moral status quo are often in need of validation and assurance from outside of work. For example, a NICU nurse who did not change jobs following her moral reckoning mentioned that she often turns to her husband or best friend for reassurance and centering when she grapples with moral dilemmas around issues of patient care, rather than her colleagues at the hospital.

;

;In addition, professionals who depart from traditional career trajectories to pursue moral values often find themselves looking outside their workplaces for moral support. Journalists who struck out on their own as freelancers, for instance, described how building a career aligned with their moral values often required looking to the public and their readers for validation that their work was moral, not within their industry.

;

;. 。 .

;

;The landscape of work is changing, yet people's aspiration to build careers with moral value remains constant. While doing so is difficult, it's also worthwhile: Our careers take up an enormous amount of our time and energy, and it's essential to feel that we're creating careers aligned with our moral values. Our work suggests that people can hold onto their moral values while building careers by staying attuned to moments of moral reckoning, questioning common purity rules, and being willing to change to whom they turn for validation.

;Disruptions have become a way of life for manufacturers. But the production and inventory planning process that many companies, especially SMEs, use are not capable of handling the uncertainty. A new inexpensive method that was developed in research involving two companies can. It doesn’t have to be automated but can be.

;Production and inventory-planning processes commonly used by companies, called sales & operations planning (S&OP), require predictable demand and supply to function properly. In the post-pandemic world, as uncertainty and disruptions have increased in frequency, this approach is no longer suited to the job.

;

;Companies, including small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), need a better system to make decisions when there is uncertainty. In research studies that my colleagues and I conducted with two companies, we devised new data analytics methods that are up to the challenge. They can be performed in Excel but also can be automated, using SQL and Python programming tools for data management, computations, and visualization. In this article, I describe how they work.

;

;;The Current S&OP Process;

;

;The predictability of demand and supply are necessary for traditional supply-chain-planning systems to work. In these systems, a manager or a cross-functional team begins by making forecasts of demand for the upcoming weeks. Near-term forecasts are frozen and converted into targets. Production and inventory flows are then planned to meet those targets at minimum cost. Performance is measured through metrics such as “days of cover,” the number of days of demand forecast covered by inventory. For instance, if I have 100 pallets of inventory on hand and the average forecast of daily demand is four pallets, then I have 25 days of cover. If I then want to increase the days of cover to 30, I will have to order 20 more pallets.

;

;This system works beautifully when there is limited uncertainty in demand and supply. If the forecast of demand is accurate and supply is reasonably certain, the days of cover can be controlled easily, and the company can focus on increasing cost efficiency, on-time fulfillment, and capacity utilization. Benefiting from this clockwork system, companies have been able to create efficient supply chains reliant on large-scale, global, single-source factories, ports, and shipping lines.

;

;This system has the added advantage of simplicity. It does not require significant data-analytics capabilities because the weekly demand forecast is a single number and the inventory plan follows from the forecast. SMEs can run the entire process on Excel spreadsheets.

; ; ;
; ;
;

;

;
; ;
; ; ;

;But even ardent supporters of the conventional S&OP process acknowledge that plans don't always succeed. Their response to an unexpected event is to make a new plan. But this can be challenging. Consider the previous example: If average weekly demand were still four pallets but actual demand varied between one to 10 pallets, then days of cover could be 100 days or it could be 10 days, so it's difficult to set a target and determine how much to order.

;

;In the post-pandemic world, when uncertainty arises almost daily from any number of sources — demand and price shocks, supply disruptions, shipping delays, and labor shortages — managers need a better system that doesn't just whipsaw in reaction to uncertainty but tells them proactively what to do and what to expect over the medium and long-term time horizons. Creating such systems requires new data analytics tools to measure uncertainty and explicitly incorporate those measures in future planning. Here is how two different companies built new models of demand uncertainty and price uncertainty to solve this problem.

;

;;A Distributor of Packaged Foods;

;

;The US distributor of ;a multinational sweet baked goods company; imports cakes and croissants from Europe for sales to retail chains in the United States. Before the pandemic, the company had a predictable lead time of about 50 days from placing an order to receiving goods in its New Jersey distribution center, including production (21 days) and ocean freight (28 days). After receiving a shipment, the company would distribute product to retail stores throughout the country. Timeliness was of the essence because shipments of perishable food products to retailers must meet a minimum shelf-life requirement.

;

;During the pandemic, shipment lead times grew significantly longer, more uncertain, and costlier. Due to the resulting uncertainty in inflows and outflows, the days of cover in the New Jersey distribution center stopped being a reliable indicator at any point in time. Planning inventory became akin to guesswork. The result: increased stockouts, an inability to meet growth targets, higher cost of waste from perishable food products, and significant senior management time spent on managing inventory item by item.

;

;To solve this problem, historical demand and shipment data, stored in Excel spreadsheets, was harvested and used to estimate the standard deviation of weekly demand forecast and supply lead times. This gave the company a measurement of the amount of uncertainty that it needed to incorporate in its plan. Then, days of cover was replaced by a new inventory planning metric: the target inventory position for each product — the sum of the forecast of demand over the lead time plus an inventory buffer for the standard deviations of demand and lead time.

;

;For example, suppose the weekly demand forecast has an average value of 25 pallets and standard deviation of three pallets, the order lead time has an average value of 10 weeks with standard deviation one week, and the company desires a 98% fill rate. Then the average forecast of demand over the lead time is 25 x 10 = 250 pallets and the desired buffer is 2 x square root of (3 x 3 x 10 + 25 x 25 x 1 x1) = 2 x 27 = 54 pallets, where the multiple 2 corresponds to the 98% fill rate and the other numbers come from the average and standard deviation of demand and lead time. The resulting target inventory position is 250 + 54 = 304 pallets.

;

;This approach was superior to days of cover because the target inventory position was computed from the lead time and uncertainties via an exact formula, whereas the target days of cover was an arbitrary number. The process was run weekly. First, data was updated, then the target inventory position was calculated in Excel, and finally order quantities were determined to make up the difference between the target and the actual inventory and checked by a manager.

;

;This new method enabled the company to replace guesswork that required experience and judgment with a standardized, unambiguous formulaic approach that workers could execute with little training. Moreover, as new data came in weekly, the new method automatically adjusted to changes in the marketplace. If the degree of uncertainty increased, the inventory target would get revised upwards. Larger inventory buffers were built for products whose demand was more uncertain. As uncertainty increased further during the pandemic, the company found that the advance planning prepared it well for the challenge.

;

;;A Manufacturer of Durable Seasonal Goods;

;

;A medium-sized ;manufacturer of recreational durable goods;, such as barbeque grills, swimming-pool equipment, and camping equipment, faced a different kind of challenge as its supply chain shifted. Previously, it sold its products through a network of dealers spread throughout the United States. Since the products were seasonal, with most of the demand occurring in May and June, the company required distributors to place orders six months in advance for optimal scheduling of manufacturing.

;

;However, a few years ago, when the company's distributors started selling online, the consumer market for the products became more competitive and prices became volatile. The distributors responded by placing fewer advance orders and more just-in-time orders during the selling season. This upended the company's S&OP process: Inventory build-ups and ramp-downs could not be planned in advance, and past sales and cash flows stopped being a predictor of the future.

;

;The novelty of this situation was that it arose from a new variable: downstream price uncertainty, which the company had previously not considered. We used daily prices from the online marketplace to measure price uncertainty and the company's historical orders data to measure the timing of orders for each product. The data told us that products with more price uncertainty received more just-in-time orders. This gave the company a method to predict when distributors would place orders as a function of price and demand uncertainty. Thus, the company was able to obtain more informed internal guidance as well as be more effective in its negotiations with distributors. In particular, it could give higher discounts for early orders for products with large price uncertainty to incentivize distributors to order early, which helped reduce inventory risk.

;

;In both examples, the companies focused on measuring uncertainty and directly including it in supply-chain planning. This enabled them to easily solve problems that previously seemed unmanageable. And the beauty of the approach is that it was inexpensive and fast to create. It took only a few months and could be implemented in Excel, which made it easy to use.

;

;As the number of products and customers grows, a company should consider automating the analytics in a programming language, such as Python, to reduce the chances of human errors and improve productivity. A good supply-chain engineer with knowledge of programming can create these tools in a few months. Typically, this would require converting all the manual data management tasks from Excel sheets into database management rules in SQL, implementing the computation of target inventory position in Python, and building visualization dashboards in Python, Tableau, PowerBI, or an equivalent tool for performance monitoring and reporting.

;

;An SME organization should automate one step at a time, starting with building a database and visualization dashboards, then creating software for estimating demand, price, and lead time uncertainty, and finally computing the target inventory position. This approach offers SMEs a fairly inexpensive way to manage their inventory and production processes in uncertain times.

What concrete practices do leaders use to consistently foster belongingness and authenticity in their organizations — especially amid all their existing deadlines and demands?

;

;We conducted hour-long structured interviews with 40 DEI award–winning or peer-nominated exemplary inclusive leaders from a wide variety of job functions, organizations, and industries. We identified five key behaviors that help leaders make their organizations more inclusive.

;

;1. Inclusive leaders strive for authenticity rather than leadership presence.

;

;The leaders prioritized authenticity and ;psychological safety;, viewing the two as essential building blocks for creating an environment where people can express themselves freely and air dissenting opinions without fear of retribution. They did this by modeling curiosity, humility, and vulnerability.

;

;For example, several interviewees criticized the idea of leadership presence, which conveys an infallible and superior image that a person has to project in order to be seen as a leader. Instead, they emphasized the importance of sharing their own vulnerabilities, citing it as a crucial ingredient for building trust and psychological safety among their team members. One leader humbly revealed his weaknesses to his staff, while another bravely shared the ups and downs of her career journey in public forums. Yet another leader took it upon herself to share her failures with her team members in an effort to normalize mistakes and foster a culture of learning and growth. Finally, a leader in a design team regularly disagreed with her boss in front of her team so that her team members knew it was OK to question authority.

;

;2. Inclusive leaders redefine the rules rather than unquestioningly following them.

;

;The exemplars of inclusive leadership were not afraid to challenge well-established practices that had outlived their relevance. They actively sought ways to detect practices that excluded certain groups of people and replaced them with new ones that gave more access to underrepresented groups.

;

;For example, one leader in a safety-focused organization broadened the organization's dress policies, including those pertaining to hair (to be more inclusive of women and African Americans) and tattoos (to be more inclusive of younger people), noting that previous practices were less related to safety and more based on stereotypes.

;

;Another leader in a professional services firm advocated for removing a candidate's full-time or part-time status from partner promotion criteria because it was irrelevant to a person's value to the organization, and it tended to penalize working mothers. One HR leader challenged managers to articulate what “culture fit” means in their organization, and formally embedded clear definitions of it into the organization's hiring guidelines. Several leaders created new team norms to make sure everyone was heard, such as rotating the order in which team members spoke during meetings or rotating the role of agenda-setter so that priorities in different areas would be voiced and addressed over time.

;

;By constantly reexamining and revising entrenched practices, inclusive leaders are able to recruit and support a more diverse group of employees who contribute new ideas and add complementary value to their organizations.

;

;3. Inclusive leaders embrace active learning and consistent implementation.

;

;The interviewed leaders emphasized that the effort to be inclusive is actively learned, rather than passively acquired. They believed that our natural habits or inclinations usually contain biases and need to be constantly examined, challenged, and changed in a planned and consistent manner to pave the way for inclusion. As a leader in a financial services firm put it, we cannot just ;hope; to recruit more women and underrepresented employees — we need to deploy intentional, systematic processes to recruit them.

;

;These intentional efforts take many forms; however, the ones that are especially useful are those that embed DEI practices into the existing processes and systems to ensure consistency and accountability. Examples include mandating diverse candidate pools in recruitment, embedding inclusion efforts into performance metrics, coaching managers to facilitate feedback-giving among their direct reports, and holding managers accountable for their direct reports' career development.

;

;To ensure accountability, for example, an HR leader in a manufacturing firm trained all managers on how to have listening sessions with their team members, then had managers share ideas for how they could modify their practices based on the responses. Another company used a tracking system to monitor representation of different demographic groups in hiring, voluntary attrition, promotions, and internal mobility, as well as employee satisfaction across different business areas, and hosted quarterly conversations with business leaders about areas to reinforce and change.

;

;Besides formal practices, there are also informal ways leaders can consistently cultivate inclusion. For example, at an insurance company, to commit to understanding different people's experiences, the mostly white senior leadership team held regular meetings where they discussed books such as ;White Fragility; and books about Black women's experience in America. Other leaders shared their practices of putting all cultural holidays and celebrations on company calendars, regularly sending out messages to not only celebrate each holiday, but also to offer some meaningful takeaways that are relevant to everyone. By doing so, they ensured that inclusion is a top-of-mind consideration and inspired individuals to actively promote inclusion, irrespective of their own personal backgrounds.

;

;By continuously pursuing and building new learning into established routines and policies that expand their default views and habits, leaders were better prepared to understand and meet the demands of a diverse workforce, creating a more vibrant workplace culture.

;

;4. Inclusive leaders ensure equal opportunity and equitable outcomes.

;

;The leaders we interviewed were highly committed to providing employees with equal opportunities to succeed. To do this, they acknowledged individuals' particular needs, especially those of team members underrepresented backgrounds. They were also acutely attuned to the invisible obstacles faced by those team members and took proactive measures to support them.

;

;For example, a law firm partner recognized the larger challenges that first-generation lawyers, who often come from underrepresented backgrounds, face compared with their non-first-generation peers. She made sure to provide additional support to these attorneys by sharing more examples of past practices, allocating more time for them to study cases, ensuring they had speaking roles in client meetings, and including more detail in their performance reviews. And a DEI officer at a global technology firm provided not only training for managers to have coaching conversations to support their team members, but also training for team members on how to ask for a raise, get a career-development plan, and obtain buy-in from their managers, as employees from marginalized groups had reported these as particularly challenging. One senior manager in a professional services firm saw herself as an amplifier for underrepresented individuals and regularly voiced their perspectives in front of senior leaders.

;

;By providing support that considers people's differing needs based on their backgrounds, leaders provided a more level playing field for all team members. When the majority members who perceived some practices as unfair pushed back, the leaders took the time to help them understand why there was a need for differentiated support, related their personal experience, generated empathy, and explained the benefits this support can engender for the whole team and organization.

;

;5. They view inclusive leadership as everyone's responsibility, not just HR's.

;

;The interviewees agreed that an organization cannot expect to nurture an inclusive environment by equipping a small cadre of leaders to take up inclusion work. In order to create an inclusive environment, everyone needs to be invested in it.

;

;A common challenge many leaders encounter is the expectation that DEI initiatives are owned and driven primarily by HR. In reality, the most successful DEI initiatives are those that are integrated into organizational core values, because core values serve to rally people around the effort and act as a powerful force against pushback and skepticism. They also allow inclusive efforts in an organization to transcend individual leaders who may come and go, sustaining the commitment to inclusion by solidifying it into the organization's DNA.

;

;In some organizations, this holistic approach to inclusion is demonstrated in the embedding of DEI into all aspects of the employee life cycle: recruitment, selection, development, and retention. In others, it's built into the way people carry out their everyday work responsibilities, rather than into specific DEI programs. Various practices bolster this whole-organization approach, such as building inclusion into organizational strategy; communicating to employees that inclusion is not an aspiration, but an expectation; building inclusion criteria into all hiring, compensation, training, promotion, and retention considerations; conveying messages of inclusion on a regular basis; having visible and consistent support for inclusion from top leaders; and developing inclusion ambassadors who represent all areas.

;

;The power of inclusive leadership

;

;All of these inclusive practices encourage all individuals in their organizations to thrive. While inclusion might be misperceived as “going easy on people” or as “just being nice to everyone,” the interviewed leaders spotlighted tangible benefits that inclusion can deliver to everyone.

;

;For example, the leaders found that a diverse and inclusive workplace is a better workplace for all, because it challenges people to come up with new ways to work with those who are different from them; allows people to collaborate in creative ways to build better products and services; generates different methods of getting things done; makes unexpected breakthroughs; instills pride in people; and supports well-being. Further, these positive employee interactions not only benefit internal stakeholders, but also help engage a wider range of customers and strengthen an organization's reputation, all of which help attract talent and increase the bottom line. To illustrate, a CEO of an engineering firm discussed a time when his company was competing head-to-head with a strong competitor in a contract bid. His company's years of nurturing diversity and inclusion won him the big contract in the end. He commented that inclusion is “growing the pie.”

;

;In sum, exemplary leaders of inclusion conscientiously leverage information, mindsets, daily practices, and organizational systems to foster inclusion. Leading inclusively calls for action, courage, and ingenuity. In our increasingly hybrid workplace, specific practices may flex to the context, but the principles we identify above remain. When practiced intentionally and adaptively, these efforts can elevate both employee well-being and measurable business outcomes.

;The benefits of implementing a business purpose are beyond doubt—those that do it successfully enjoy  than their nonpurposeful competitors. Nearly nine out of 10 CEOs say their business has a purpose. But how many businesses use purpose to make meaningful change and drive sustainable growth?

;

;Today, all organizations are working against a global backdrop of geopolitical change that includes climate crises, rampant inflation, and the steady march of generative artificial intelligence. ;
;
;

;If your organization struggles with putting purpose at the center of its business strategy, these five steps can help you move from statement to action.

;

;

;Let's backtrack a little. Defining a purpose statement is a challenge for nearly half of the leaders in the survey. Your purpose should also be relevant and meaningful to all internal and external stakeholders. They need to connect with it. That's a lot to ask from something that starts its life as a written statement of intent.

;

;So here's the first question to consider when defining your purpose: Is it actionable? Paradoxically, a purpose statement should not be achievable. (Save that for your organizational ambition.) Set out a purpose that is evergreen, something you always strive to improve on. The simplest purpose statements are often the most powerful and enduring.

;

;;2. Align leadership with your purpose;;.;

;

;To have a powerful purpose that resonates with your entire workforce, you have to work from the top down. The executive leadership team needs to buy into the purpose if it is to be embedded effectively, energize the organization, and become the compass for every decision.

;

;As workforces increasingly work in silos, remotely and virtually, it becomes harder to make everyone across the organization aware of your purpose—let alone use it as a jumping-off point for action.

;

;Only 26% of our survey respondents say purpose helps them align senior leaders. That marks a missed opportunity; we've seen firsthand the powerful motivating effect purpose has at the executive leadership level.

;
;
;
; ;
;
;
;

;

;While salary and benefits will always be important to employees, ;people now also want to work for organizations with a clear purpose;, where they can make a meaningful contribution.

;

;并非每个组织都渴望解决其问题。在没有明显的绩效危机的情况下，领导者往往会紧抓现状而低估其风险。这种对变革的抵制可以以多种形式出现，其中一些难以解读。这里有 10 个迹象，表明你的公司可能试图让你放慢脚步，无论你在层级结构中处于何种位置。

;

;;1.一个特别工作组正在被指派来解决这个问题。;

;

;一个由改革者组成的小而勇敢的团队是一回事，但另一个是。事实上，我们经常建议加快行动。事实证明，大多数特遣部队并不符合这一特点。你怎么知道？如果您被要求依赖缺乏地位、合法性或决策权的结构或流程，或者拥有上述任何一项的人的赞助，那么它不太可能帮助您有所作为。

; < h2>;<强>;2。我们感谢您付出的时间和努力。 ;;

;如果您怀疑自己被纵容或被解雇，那么您可能就是这样。顺便说一句，这与不同意不同，无论诊断结果如何，这都是完全可以接受的反应。作为变革者，你的义务是为你的想法提供有说服力的案例。您同事的义务是真诚地与他们交往，而不是不加批判地同意您的观点。

;

;;3. ;;人们怀疑组织是否（真的）有问题。;

;

;做好准备，你的一些同事会反驳你认为公司有问题的前提。顾名思义，残酷的事实是难以面对的。对于表明缺乏充分包容等文化问题的数据尤其如此。 Stay strong.流畅地讲述您今天收集到的证明问题确实存在的证据，以及有关组织为此付出的代价的共鸣故事。

;

;;4. ;;你被要求回应身份不明的批评者的严重关切。;

;

;这些交流通常以一些变化开始，“作为你的朋友，我认为你应该知道人们在说什么。”这通常是一种让你受到控制的策略，而不是向你提供有用的信息。不要上当并对谣言和道听途说做出反应。鼓励你的批评者说出自己的想法，这样你就可以直接解决他们的担忧，这很可能是有道理的。协作发生在白天。

;

;;5. ;;“法律问题”的幽灵正在被唤起。;

;

;解决这一问题的方法是直接与法律团队合作，该团队通常由人组成他们比那些使用他们名字的批评者更有创造力、更灵活、更注重解决方案。律师很少像非律师所说的那样无法容忍风险、令人扫兴，所以尽早与他们合作。

;

;;6. ;;您的同事指出了所有需要解决的;其他;问题。;

;

;此回复假设存在某种可测量的限制公司吸收积极变革的能力——而你正危险地接近这条线。人们往往会低估公司适应更好现实的能力（以及持续无所作为的真正成本）。您提出的问题需要快速响应，这反映了挫败感、平庸，以及某些组织中现状的真正痛苦。

;

;;7. ;;你不断听说未来的状态，变革的条件将会好得多。;

;

;这可能是我们看到的最常见的抵制表达：幻想在未来的某个时刻改变事情会更容易。根据我们的经验，这种情况几乎从来不会发生，而且通常情况恰恰相反。你现在拥有的清晰度和动力是巨大的资产，但它们也是易逝的。在大多数情况下，“现在的紧迫性”会赢得胜利，尤其是当你周围的人的成功和福祉处于危险之中时。

;

;;8.行动的时间表越来越长。;

;

;这是另一种常见的拖延策略，是针对第 6 项和第 7 项中表达的担忧提出的解药。您的诊断在概念层面上得到了接受，但提议的变革的时间表漫长而模糊。将这种发展视为一种生存威胁。当谈到解决关键任务问题时，现在就是采取行动的最佳时机。

;

;;9. ;;你的同事认为他们可以等你。;

;

;管理思想领袖 Earl Sasser 称之为“肾结石管理”——假设这也会过去。明确表示你不会去任何地方，最好是面带微笑。如果你不是老板，那就每天早上带着一杯咖啡出现在她的办公室，就像她喜欢的那样，直到你让她参与进来。顺便说一句，这一举动从未让我们失望过。

;

;;10。您不断听到，“我们已经尝试过了。”;

;

;公司可能已经在努力解决您所提出的问题的某些版本，除了遗留问题之外，没有什么可以展示的的挫败感和愤世嫉俗。如果是这样，请做好功课，并从出现的问题中吸取教训。无论如何，背景会发生变化，包括你愿意在这些问题上发挥领导作用的非常重要的背景。 ;您之前;没有尝试过，这将会带来很大的不同。

; ;摘要。   ; ;

;技术进步和新的数字产品一直被用来改善运营。但事实是，科技往往会让官僚主义变得更糟。电子健康记录 (EHR) 被誉为解决纸质系统效率低下的良方。但现在的研究表明，医生一半的时间都花在管理电子病历和案头工作上，欺骗了病人并加剧了倦怠。夏威夷太平洋健康中心 (HPH) 的 Melinda Ashton 博士提出了一个简单而彻底的解决方案：摆脱愚蠢的东西 (GROSS)。她和 HPH 工作人员设计了一个简单的表格，用于报告设计不当、不必要或毫无意义的任务。简单的修复会直接实施，更多涉及的改进则由相关小组审查其可行性。凭借集中的领导和后续行动，GROSS 为整个 HPH 系统以及采用该实践的其他卫生系统节省了数千个小时。

; ;
;
;
;
;
; ;阅读西班牙语;

;

;数字技术遍及各个行业已被证明是简化流程和自动化工作流程的强大工具。在医疗保健领域，电子健康记录 (EHR) 的引入被誉为解决纸质系统效率低下的突破性方法。但正如许多医疗保健提供者现在了解到的那样，将毫无意义或设计不当的流程数字化可能会让员工更难完成工作。这些数字是显而易见的：《内科年鉴》中的一项研究显示，门诊医生仅花费 27他们每天 % 的时间用于面对面的患者护理，而一半的时间花在电子病历和案头工作上。

;

;这种不平衡是三重威胁。它欺骗了患者，剥夺了他们与医疗保健提供者在一起的宝贵时间。它加剧了护士和医生的倦怠，他们认为过度的官僚主义是;主要原因;。而且成本高昂——美国医疗保健系统每年在管理上的支出高达 1 万亿美元，占总支出的四分之一。

;

;尽管有些人对此抱有希望 ;生成式人工智能将有助于简化文书工作，;这些预测仍然是推测性的。与此同时，有一种行之有效的补救措施可以减轻行政负担。该解决方案并不依赖于花哨的算法，而是致力于消除官僚主义的低效率和简化工作流程。以夏威夷太平洋健康中心 (HPH) 为例，这是一个非盈利系统，在阿罗哈州的四家医院拥有 7,000 名员工。

; ; ;
; ;
;
; 洞察中心集合
;

;运营新时代

;
; 提高效率并增强弹性。
;
; ;
; ; ;

;故事始于 2017 年儿科医生 Melinda Ashton 博士担任 HPH 首席质量官。在她的角色中，阿什顿越来越担心大量的行政任务正在侵蚀医务人员直接照顾病人的时间。在 HPH 内部，人们对不必要的忙碌工作和繁琐的系统的抱怨越来越多。医生和护士尤其沮丧的是，他们每天花费大量时间机械地点击屏幕上迷宫般的提示，每当他们需要更新患者的护理记录时，屏幕上就会弹出提示。

;

;当一组护士决定计算他们和他们的同伴记录他们完成每小时查房这一简单事实所花费的时间。研究小组估计，这项敷衍的任务每月要耗费 1,700 个护理时间。

;

;这一发现是困扰临床医生的不必要摩擦的完美象征，将阿什顿推向了崩溃的边缘。她大胆而务实，向高管同事提出了一个激进的想法：召集 HPH 的所有医务人员开展一场“摆脱愚蠢的东西”运动。这个直率的名字引起了高管们的不满，一些人建议使用“行政简化”等更温和的术语，但阿什顿坚持自己的立场。诚实地承认问题并明确解决问题的意图至关重要。

;

;;“摆脱愚蠢的东西”建议;

;

;摆脱Stupid Stuff (GROSS) 于 2017 年 10 月推出。鼓励临床医生识别 EHR 中设计不当、不必要或完全无意义的任何内容。提交表格非常简单，可以在 HPH 的互联网上轻松访问。

;
; ;

;;;查看数据和视觉中的更多 HBR 图表;< /i>;;;

;
;

;为了引起轰动，阿什顿参观了 HPS 的四家医院。她分享了行政荒谬的生动例子，并邀请她的同事加入竞选活动。

;

;大多数早期提名都是针对毫无意义的任务。一名青少年肿瘤科护士指出，十多年来，她一直尽职尽责地记录患者的“脐带护理”情况。荒谬吗？青少年没有脐带。一名新生儿护士提出了另一项同样愚蠢的任务：每次给婴儿换尿布时都必须检查三个方框，以表明她的小病人是否出现尿失禁、大便失禁或两者兼而有之。

;

;其他提名针对流程这是必要的，但需要大幅提升效率。例如，从急诊室出院的患者必须对就诊后的总结进行数字签名，然后打印、扫描并上传回系统。

;

;;从想法到行动;

;

;该倡议实施的第一年，HPH 员工提交了近 200 条建议。这些内容由 Ashton 部门的两位护理领导进行了审核，他们在 IT 和质量改进方面都拥有丰富的经验。 GROSS 核心团队开发了一种简单但有效的分类机制。

;
; ;

;;;查看数据和视觉中的更多 HBR 图表 ;;;;

;
;

;简单的修复，例如删除非新生儿患者的“绳索”提示，由 GROSS 团队直接处理。需要进一步审查和详细说明的想法由现有质量和 EHR 工作处理这些团队代表不同的医院领域，对提名进行审查和优先排序。当一个“愚蠢的东西”想法获得批准时，工作组将邀请原始提名背后的个人帮助重新设计。

; <在某些情况下，找到解决方案还意味着与对特定实践的优点有不同观点的临床小组进行联络。例如，急诊科的医生更喜欢填写简单的一次性抗生素处方，而住院医生则热衷于防止给药延迟，通常会选择重复处方，这需要更多时间才能输入。由工作组来确定这些冲突并设计最佳解决方案。

;

;一小部分提交的内容（大约八分之一）遇到了重大监管或技术障碍，并被判定为“不合格”。这个时候有可能。”当这种情况发生时，GROSS 团队会写一份回复，解释为什么修复不可行。我们的目标始终是承认每一项提名，并在重新设计的障碍似乎无法克服时保持透明。

;

;;更广泛的影响;

;

;GROSS 的第二年将产生另外 300 项提名。在所有可行的想法中，大约 10% 涉及明显愚蠢的活动，可以立即终止； 15% 的人指出临床沟通和对必要工作流程的支持方面存在差距；其余 75% 确定了重新设计机会以提高效率和效果。除了在 HPH 中节省了数千个小时之外，GROSS 计划还对组织的文化产生了影响，主要是通过授权一线团队成员挑战那些使他们的工作变得不必要的困难和低效的系统和流程。正如阿什顿在《新英格兰医学杂志》的一篇文章中所说：;新英格兰医学杂志;：; “……我们周围有很多愚蠢的事情，尽管我们收到的许多提名并不是为了做出重大改变，但来自认可和改进我们日常工作的小胜利确实很重要。”

;

;其他医院包括克利夫兰诊所和;西奈山卫生系统;在内的系统已注意到 Dr.阿什顿的工作实施了他们自己版本的“摆脱愚蠢的东西”。看到在整个医疗保健系统中推广这种方法的潜力，美国医学会 (AMA) 推出了;GROSS 模块< /a>; 作为其标志性实践改进计划“STEPS Forward”的一部分。

;

;;前线主动性和情报;

;

;博士。阿什顿的个人领导力和主动性是夏威夷太平洋航空​​公司成功的关键。她毫不拐弯抹角——她直言不讳地指出这些“愚蠢的东西”的本质。但这一努力的真正魔力在于利用该组织集体智慧的力量。总部的人，无论意图多么善意，都不是在第一线，因此无法衡量官僚愚蠢行为的真正成本。护士、医生和其他在第一线工作的人看到了系统的不足之处。

;

;然而，仅有想法是不够的。阿什顿博士和他的团队之所以成功，是因为他们在后续工作中遵守纪律、深思熟虑。 GROSS 不仅仅是一个电子意见箱，它是一个跨部门和学科过滤、优先考虑和执行有前途的想法的系统。该计划产生了有意义的成果——以多种方式改善临床医生和患者的生活。其重要性足以证明根除多余官僚主义的艰苦努力是值得的。

;

;面对根深蒂固的规范和流程，人们很容易屈服于无助感，接受现状作为不可改变的现实；人们也很容易相信技术会解决所有问题。然而，夏威夷太平洋医疗保健公司 (Hawaii Pacific Healthcare) 的 GROSS 计划的故事却提供了令人信服的反面叙述。这个故事提醒我们，通过简单、智能的流程改进，我们确实可以挑战和重塑束缚我们的操作系统。
